justification: The text explains that the beauty-contest game is used to illustrate and classify “different degrees of sophistication,” with most people falling at level-1 or level-2, thereby operationalising depth of strategic reasoning.

topic_or_construct: recursive belief inference in cooperative decisions
justification: Participants played a stag-hunt game in which fitting a ‘theory-of-mind’ model best captured behaviour, indicating the game serves as the instrument for measuring recursive belief inference.
In the competitive inspector game, the ‘influence’ learning model (level-2 mentalizing) best explained behaviour, showing the task measures second-order belief inference abilities.

During an advice-giving task where two advisers compete for a client, neural and behavioural indices of how participants manage social influence were analysed, making this task the measure of the construct.
Computational modelling of behaviour in the multi-round economic exchange game classified investors into level-0, level-1 or level-2 players, hence the game operationalises ToM sophistication.
The chapter states that vicarious reward learning is underpinned by an ‘observational reward prediction error (oRPE),’ identifying this computational signal as the measure of the construct.
Action imitation is described as being ‘explained in a reinforcement-learning framework, with an action prediction error (APE),’ marking the APE as the metric for the imitation construct.
The text notes that an inverse reinforcement-learning model ‘best explained participants’ behaviour’ during emulation, indicating the IRL model functions as the measurement tool for this construct.
